title: Russia Orders Retreat From Kherson, a Serious Reversal in the Ukraine War
abstract: Russia’s position had grown perilous in Kherson, a strategic city and one of the biggest prizes seized in its Ukraine invasion, but Russian hawks reacted angrily to the withdrawal.
byline: By Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer, Dan Bilefsky, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski

multimedia.caption: Ukrainian soldiers in the Kherson area on Wednesday. The announced retreat from the city is one of the most significant setbacks for Russia in the war so far.

title: A Vatican Auditor Says He Dug Up Too Much Dirt, and Was Buried
abstract: Libero Milone is suing the Vatican for wrongful dismissal after he said he found cardinals siphoning off funds. The Vatican has hit him with a criminal investigation of its own.

multimedia.caption: Pope Francis meeting with Libero Milone, now a former Vatican auditor general, in a 2016 photo released by a Vatican newspaper.

title: Weed Is Now Legal in Thailand. How Long Will the High Times Last?
abstract: Cannabis shops have multiplied since the drug was decriminalized, with caveats, in June. But some lawmakers are pushing for tighter regulation.

title: These Farmers Tried to Stop Yet Another Coal Mine. What Happened Next?
abstract: In South Africa, a township’s battle over a new mine shows the challenge of a nation dependent on coal, but also desperate to leave it behind.

des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

title: 84 Years Later, a New Look at the Nazi Attacks of Kristallnacht
abstract: Newly released photographs of the assaults on Jews during the 1938 pogrom, which is widely commemorated as the start of the Holocaust, had been kept by a former American serviceman.

multimedia.caption: A photo released by Yad Vashem, the World Holocaust Remembrance Center, of German Nazis and civilians watching the ransacking of Jewish property during the attacks, known as Kristallnacht, taken most likely in the town of Fürth, Germany, on Nov. 10, 1938.

title: An Outburst Threatens the French Far Right’s Effort to Go Mainstream
abstract: For the first time, the National Rally is the main opposition party in Parliament. But can it use its new perch to convince voters it has changed?
byline: By Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: Brittney Griner Heads for a Russian Penal Colony
abstract: The U.S. basketball star, detained for more than eight months so far, is being transferred to an undisclosed prison in Russia, her lawyers said. The United States denounced the move.

title: A Girl Loses Her Mother in the Jungle, and a Migrant Dream Dies
abstract: The pandemic, climate change and growing conflict are forcing a seismic shift in global migration. In few places is that more clear than a perilous crossing called the Darién Gap.

title: Jordan Is Running Out of Water, a Grim Glimpse of the Future
abstract: The small Middle Eastern nation is already one of the driest countries in the world and rising heat, coupled with a growing population, is making things much worse.

title: After Near Wipeout in Election, Israeli Left Wonders: What Now?
